lines.text: Hey Sam, pass the salt please.
Salt? GET IT YOURSELF!
Uh oh, that'll cost you about...
Salt? Why didn't you say so. Here's your salt, Bunny, I hope you like it.
[Brings it across the table to him then walks back]
Ooh that rackin' frackin'...
The pepper please.
PEPPER! WE... Uh, yeah the pepper. Coming right up.
[Walks to the end of the table and gives it to Bugs]
Ooh that rackin' frackin'...
Oh Sam!
Oh no.
How about the olives?
But Sire, there is no more money. Your uncle, the king, has cut off your allowance.
You know the penalty for not having the books balanced!
Oh no. Not the 'nose-in-the-book' penalty.
Yeah, the nose-in-the-book.
[Advisor puts his nose in the book and Sam slams it]
WE'VE GOTTA GET SOME MONEY!
I got it licked, rabbit. I don't get mad no more. Watch this.
[His servants kick him, throw a pie at him and bash him with a rolling pin]
See? Ha ha. I can take it. Ha ha ha!

[to camera]
I ain't got the heart tell him he's used up all the money.
[first lines]
B-but sire, there is no more money. Your uncle the king has cut off your allowance.

[angrily answering the door]
Well, what do you want?
Good evening. My company has selected you, under no obligation, to be the proud owner of legal tender amounting to...

[Slamming the door]
We don't want any!
...£1 million!

[Opening the door again]
£1 million? Well, come right in! Welcome to the house of Sam.
[last lines]
I haven't got the heart to tell him that he's used up all the money.

[Pounding on the bathroom door]
Get out of there!
[Bugs opens the door knocking him out]

[Bugs peeks out and shrugs his shoulders]
Come out of there you bladder spattin' nagger trap or I'll...
I heard you that's going to cost you four hundred pounds
[Sam growls]
and thirty five shillings!
[Sam bangs his head on the piano in frustration]
Hey doc what's that song you're playing?, I like it!

[Muttering]
Dirty son of a battle strommy crat!, If this keeps up I won't have anything left!
[Gets an idea]
I'll get rid of him and make it look like an accident!

[playing on the piano and singing loudly]
I dream of Jeanie, she's a light brown hare!
[Sam is trying to sleep, but Bugs' singing and piano playing disturb his sleep]

[screaming]
STOP THAT MUSIC, YA CRAZY RACKIN', FRACKIN', VARMINT RABBIT!

[offended]
Well! That should be worth, eh, £400.

[calming down]
I was only kidding. How about singing me to sleep with that "Brahms' Lullaby"? What do you say, Frankie boy?
Well, maybe.
